Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Damage Tolerant 3-D Periodic Interpenetrating Phase Composites with Enhanced Mechanical Performance - Design, Fabrication, Analysis and Testing

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this award is to study high-performance carbon-polymer periodic interpenetrating phase composites (IPCs) with enhanced mechanical properties (including stiffness, strength, impact resistance, toughness, energy dissipation, and damage tolerance) through an integrated approach combining design, fabrication, analysis and experiment. Geometries based on triply periodic minimal surfaces and 3-D microtrusses will be used to optimally design microstructures of the proposed IPCs, and 3-D direct-write printing technologies will be employed to fabricate them. Analytical and computational micromechanics models will be developed to simulate the IPCs, and various tests will be conducted to characterize the fabricated IPCs and to validate the proposed models. It is anticipated that the findings of this proposed research will provide guidelines for engineering and tailoring IPCs to achieve optimized properties.

The successful completion of the proposed research will lead to new structure-property-function relationships needed for achieving new and improved mechanical properties of IPCs, thereby significantly improving our current understanding of IPCs with enhanced mechanical performance. The proposed project will provide a demonstration of the modern concept of materials-by-design. It will offer an example of futuristic composite material technology. The research methodology, tools, and results generated in this project will be documented and used to improve both undergraduate and graduate curricula, which will enable engineering students to access cutting-edge research facilities and acquire new knowledge. The integrated educational plan will greatly enhance the students' learning experience, challenge their intellectual curiosity and motivate them to pursue careers in research and education. New findings will be made available on the Internet and to K-12 students through outreach activities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Summary of the Outcomes

 

The following is a summary of the results of this completed NSF project .

 

Intellectual Merit:

Constructed micromechanics models for 3-D printable interpenetrating phase composites (IPCs) using triply periodic minimal surface (TPMS) and rod-connected unit cell models and finite element and meshfree methods; solved the Eshelby-type problem of an arbitrary-shape polygonal inclusion embedded in a homogeneous isotropic elastic material using a simplified strain gradient elasticity theory (SSGET); derived general solutions for the problems of an elastic half-space and an elastic half-plane, each subjected to a symmetrically distributed normal force of arbitrary profile, using the SSGET and Fourier transforms; solved the generalized half-plane and half-space Cerruti problems with surface effects using Gurtin and Murdoch’s surface elasticity theory; developed non-classical models for beams and plates using a modified couple stress theory, a surface elasticity theory and a two-parameter elastic foundation model; provided an analytical model for peeling of a viscoelastic thin film adhesively bonded to a rigid substrate using a Bernoulli-Euler beam theory for viscoelastic materials; proposed a new homogenization method using Eshelby tensors based on the SSGET; extended Hill’s lemma for the Cauchy continuum to non-Cauchy continua using the SSGET.

These contributions have been reported in 19 journal papers, 19 conference publications and 1 M.S. thesis, which are detailed in the publication list attached.

 

Broader Impacts:  

Opportunities for training and development provided - Three students (2 Ph.D., 1 M.S.) received research training while working on the project at UTD and SMU. The M.S. student joined the work force in the U.S. right after his graduation, and the two doctoral students have completed the required course work and passed the Ph.D. qualifying exams at SMU.  

Outreach activities undertaken: In each year of the project duration, the PI reached out to visit relevant institutions and to discuss the findings from this NSF project. These institutions include the Naval Research Lab, Sandia National Labs, Peking University, Fudan University, Xi’an Jiaotong University, Lanzhou University, and University of Science and Technology of Beijing. The seminars given at these places were well received, and the feedback gathered at these institutions was quite helpful.    

 


Last Modified: 10/06/2016
Modified by: Xin-Lin Gao
